2000.info: The start game event is triggered at the very beginning of the game (after the game finishes loading, don't wait for intro movie to finish). This is used to compute things like time spent in game.

args.name: version
args.info: version identifier for the current build of the game

args.name: game_time
args.info: The time since the beginning of the game

args.name: round
args.info: The round since the beginning

2010.info: The exit game event is triggered when the game is quit. This is used to compute things like time spent in game. Depending on platform this may / may not be possible. NOTE: 'quit' also means navigating away from game.

args.name: session_duration
args.info: millisecond count since start of game

2020.info: The start round event is triggered at the start of a round. There are multiple rounds per level. This event provides information about the game characteristics of the round (i.e. resources, objectives, setup). It is used in calculating things like time spent in a round (for speed and accuracy), attempts at solving a round, and the number of rounds the player has visited (exposures).

args.name: starting_round_number
args.info: the number of the round that is about to start

args.name: round_target
args.info: round information

args.name: size
args.info: size of item needed to pass round with 1 being the smallest size

args.name: type
args.info: type of item being selected e.g. tub, water, soap

args.name: animal
args.info: the animal the player is selecting an item for

args.name: options
args.info: list of the sizes of the items from left to right

args.name: animals
args.info: list of animals from left to right (pig, cow, sheep, etc)

args.name: difficulty_stage
args.info: the difficulty stage of the current level

2030.info: The beat round event is triggered when the player finishes a round. This event is used for calculating time spent in a round (for speed and accuracy), attempts at solving a round, and the number of rounds the player has completed (completion).

args.name: beat_round_number
args.info: the number of the round that has just been completed

args.name: duration
args.info: the duration of the round in milliseconds. Time between start round and beat round.

args.name: round_target
args.info: round information

args.name: size
args.info: size of item needed to pass round with 1 being the smallest size

args.name: type
args.info: type of item being selected e.g. tub, water, soap

args.name: animal
args.info: the animal the player is selecting an item for

args.name: difficulty_stage
args.info: the difficulty stage of the current level

args.name: misses
args.info: the number of incorrect size objects clicked

2040.info: The start level event is triggered when a new level begins (at the same time as the start round event for the first round in the level). This event is used for calculating time spent in a level (for speed and accuracy), and the number of levels the player has completed (completion).

args.name: starting_level_number
args.info: the number of the level that has just started

args.name: difficulty_stage
args.info: the starting level's difficulty stage

2050.info: The advanced level event is triggered when a round has been completed and the player has met the requirements to advance to the next difficulty stage (occurs at the same time as the beat round event for the last round in the previous level). This event is used for calculating time spent in a level (for speed and accuracy), and the number of levels the player has completed (completion).

args.name: beat_level_number
args.info: the number of the level that has just beat

args.name: beat_difficulty_stage
args.info: the beat level's difficulty stage

args.name: duration
args.info: the duration of the level in milliseconds. Time between start level and advance level.

args.name: misses
args.info: the text or description of the instruction

2080.info: The movie started event triggers when an intro or outro movie starts to play. It identifies the movie being played. This is used to determine how long players spend watching the movies (more relevant after the first play through when the skip option is available).

args.name: movie_id
args.info: the identifier for the movie that was playing

args.name: duration
args.info: the duration of the media playback in milliseconds

args.name: description
args.info: the text or description of the instruction

2081.info: The movie skipped event triggers when the player presses the skip button during an intro or outro movie. It identifies the movie being played. This is used to determine how long players spend watching the movies (more relevant after the first play through when the skip option is available).

args.name: movie_id
args.info: the identifier for the movie that was playing

args.name: duration
args.info: the duration of the media playback in milliseconds

args.name: time_played
args.info: the time the media has been playing milliseconds when the button is pressed

args.name: description
args.info: the text or description of the instruction

2083.info: The movie ended event triggers when an intro or outro movie ends. It identifies the movie being played. This is used to determine how long players spend watching the movies (more relevant after the first play through when the skip option is available).

args.name: movie_id
args.info: the identifier for the movie that was playing

args.name: duration
args.info: the duration of the media playback in milliseconds

args.name: time_played
args.info: the time the media has been playing milliseconds when the button is pressed

args.name: description
args.info: the text or description of the instruction

3010.info: The system-initiated instruction event occurs when the game delivers instructions to the player. It contains information that describes the content of the instruction. This event differs from events 3020 and 3021 as it captures instructions that are not given in response to player action. These events are used to determine the effectiveness of the instructions. We can answer questions like, 'did players who received instruction X do better than those who did not?'

args.name: media_type
args.info: the type of media that has just played

args.name: total_duration
args.info: the estimated duration of the media playback in milliseconds (if it ran uninterrupted)

args.name: description
args.info: the text or description of the instruction

args.name: identifier
args.info: a unique identifier for this piece of instruction

3110.info: The end of system-initiated instruction event occurs when the game finishes delivering instructions to the player. It contains information that describes the content of the instruction including duration. These events are used to determine the effectiveness of the instructions and the amount of time they consume. We can answer questions like, 'how much time elapsed while the game was presenting instruction?'

args.name: media_type
args.info: the type of media that has just played

args.name: duration
args.info: the duration of the media playback in milliseconds

args.name: description
args.info: the text or description of the instruction

args.name: identifier
args.info: a unique identifier for this piece of instruction

3020.info: The system-initiated feedback (Incorrect) event occurs when the game starts delivering feedback to the player in response to an incorrect round attempt (pressing the go button with the incorrect answer). It contains information that describes the content of the instruction. These events are used to determine the effectiveness of the feedback. We can answer questions like, 'did players who received feedback X do better than those who did not?'

args.name: media_type
args.info: the type of media that has just played

args.name: total_duration
args.info: the estimated duration of the media playback in milliseconds (if it ran uninterrupted)

args.name: description
args.info: the text or description of the instruction

args.name: identifier
args.info: a unique identifier for this piece of instruction

3120.info: The end of system-initiated feedback (Incorrect) event occurs when the game finishes delivering feedback to the player in response to an incorrect round attempt (pressing the go button with the incorrect answer). It contains information that describes the content of the instruction. These events are used to determine the effectiveness of the feedback. We can answer questions like, 'how much time elapsed while the game was presenting feedback?'

args.name: media_type
args.info: the type of media that has just played

args.name: duration
args.info: the duration of the media playback in milliseconds

args.name: description
args.info: the text or description of the instruction

args.name: identifier
args.info: a unique identifier for this piece of instruction

3021.info: The system-initiated feedback (Correct) event occurs when the game starts delivering feedback to the player in response to a correct round attempt (pressing the go button with the correct answer). It contains information that describes the content of the instruction, and will likely occur in conjunction with a beat round event. These events are used to determine the effectiveness of the feedback. We can answer questions like, 'did players who received feedback X do better than those who did not?'

args.name: media_type
args.info: the type of media that has just played

args.name: total_duration
args.info: the estimated duration of the media playback in milliseconds (if it ran uninterrupted)

args.name: description
args.info: the text or description of the instruction

args.name: identifier
args.info: a unique identifier for this piece of instruction

3121.info: The end of system-initiated feedback (Correct) event occurs when the game finishes delivering feedback to the player in response to a correct round attempt (pressing the go button with the correct answer). It contains information that describes the duration and content of the instruction, and will likely occur in conjunction with a beat round event. These events are used to determine the effectiveness of the feedback. We can answer questions like, 'how much time elapsed while the game was presenting feedback?'

args.name: media_type
args.info: the type of media that has just played
the duration of the media playback in milliseconds
args.name: duration
description
args.info: the text or description of the instruction

args.name: identifier
args.info: a unique identifier for this piece of instruction

4020.info: This event occurs when the player clicks on an item on the shelf of items. It contains information about the item that was clicked, the correctness of the action, and where the action occurred. This event is used to calculate accuracy and to diagnose player strategies and understanding.

args.name: size
args.info: size of the item clicked with 1 being the smallest size

args.name: item_type
args.info: type of the item clicked e.g. tub, water, soap

args.name: position
args.info: the position of the item on the shelf with 1 being the left-most item

args.name: animal
args.info: the animal the player is selecting an item for

args.name: correct
args.info: was this the correct type of size item?

4070.info: This event occurs when the player clicks on something that isn't covered elsewhere. It can be useful in determining if there are attractive distractions (things the player think should do something, but don't) in the game, or diagnosing players who are having mechanical difficulties (near misses).

args.name: position
args.info: position of the click

args.name: x
args.info: X position of the click

args.name: y
args.info: Y position of the click

4080.info: This event occurs when the player hovers the mouse over an interactive object. It contains information about the object under the mouse, and the duration of the hover. This event can be used to diagnose things like planning (are they hovering the mouse over tiles for long periods before they use those tiles), and determine which objects the player thinks are important.

args.name: dwell_time
args.info: how long the mouse cursor dwells over the object when the player dwells for longer than 1sec

args.name: object
args.info: the object the mouse was hovering over

4444.info: Example of a game-specific event, not stored in the event dictionary

args.name: dwell_time
args.info: how long the mouse cursor dwells over the object when the player dwells for longer than 1sec
